Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

block.p: LEAD: Sept. 11, 1973: The armed forces, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, overthrow the Socialist-Communist coalition Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens. Mr. Allende dies of bullet wounds; his doctor says he committed suicide, but family members and many supporters later say he was killed. Sept. 11, 1973: The armed forces, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, overthrow the Socialist-Communist coalition Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens. Mr. Allende dies of bullet wounds; his doctor says he committed suicide, but family members and many supporters later say he was killed. Hundreds of leftists are killed or disappear after being arrested; tens of thousands are imprisoned or sent into exile. June 20, 1974: General Pinochet becomes supreme chief of the nation, retaining his post as president of the military junta. April 5, 1976: U.S. suspends arms sales to Chile, citing human rights violations. Sept. 26, 1976: Mr. Allende's Foreign Minister, Orlando Letelier, and an American friend are killed by a car bomb in Washington. The United States later blames the Chilean secret police. July 9, 1977: General Pinochet outlines a political program calling for the military to remain in power at least 11 more years. Jan. 4, 1978: General Pinochet calls a referendum to seek support; he wins, but opposition leaders charge fraud. July 24, 1978: General Pinochet dismisses the air force commander, Gen. Gustavo Leigh, who had advocated a gradual withdrawal of the armed forces from power. Sept. 11, 1980: General Pinochet wins support in a referendum for a constitution providing for transition to a restricted democracy and confirming his presidency until 1989. The opposition claims fraud. March 11, 1981: General Pinochet is sworn in as President under the new Constitution. May 11, 1983: Fed by a deep economic crisis, protests against military rule break out. Aug. 25, 1985: Eleven political parties, backed by the Catholic Church, sign an accord calling for a transition to democracy. The Government rejects call for talks. Sept. 7, 1986: A leftist guerrilla group, the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, ambushes a presidential motorcade.

General Pinochet is unhurt, but 5 bodyguards are killed and 11 wounded. Aug. 25, 1988: General Pinochet lifts all states of emergency. Aug. 30, 1988: Military chiefs name General Pinochet as sole candidate in presidential plebiscite, a yes-or-no vote on whether he should serve an eight-year term in a transition to democracy. Sept. 1, 1988: General Pinochet announces that the remaining 430 Chilean political exiles may return. Oct. 5, 1988: Chileans vote in plebiscite. Sources: Associated Press, Reuters
